The cells of D. hopiensis KR-140 are typically spherical or slightly irregular in shape, with a diameter ranging from 1 to 2 micrometers.

One of the distinctive features of D. hopiensis KR-140 is its extraordinary resistance to ionizing radiation. This bacterium can survive exposure to high doses of gamma radiation, which is a property shared by other members of the Deinococcus genus. This radiation resistance is thought to be attributed to the species' efficient DNA repair mechanisms and the presence of carotenoid pigments that protect the cells from oxidative damage.

Additionally, D. hopiensis KR-140 has been observed to thrive in environments with limited nutrient availability and can utilize a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources. This metabolic versatility and adaptability contribute to the species' ability to survive in diverse and challenging environmental conditions.

The potential applications of D. hopiensis KR-140 include bioremediation, radiation-resistant biosensors, and the development of novel biotechnological processes. Further research on this extremophilic bacterium may provide insights into the mechanisms that enable certain organisms to withstand extreme stresses, which could have implications for various fields of study, such as astrobiology and environmental microbiology.
